p: Biodiversity has been identified as a key determinant for the quality and functioning of ecosystems world‐wide (Díaz & Cabido 2001; Cardinale, Palmer & Collins 2002). The currently ongoing decline in biodiversity threatens the ability of ecosystems to adapt to changing conditions and hampers the provisioning of ecosystem services, and thus represents one of the greatest challenges for humanity (Bellard et al. 2012). Changes in land use and climate have been identified as the main drivers of this decline (Sala 2000). Particularly, forest ecosystems are under pressure, as climate change may threaten forest‐dependent species across a wide range of species groups (Thomas et al. 2004). The vulnerability of forest biodiversity along with the fact that the majority of terrestrial species depend on forest ecosystems underlines the key role of forests in conservation management (Myers et al. 2000; Parrotta, Wildburger & Mansourian 2012).
